facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 2, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 356 of 1964 and Ref. No. 15 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 2, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 356 of 1964 and Ref. No. 15 of 1964.

facts.text: High Court affirmed conviction for offences under ss. 302, 307 and 324, Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has appealed from the judgment of the High Court at Allahabad affirming his conviction for offences under ss. 302, 307 and 324, Indian Penal Code

facts.text: High Court confirmed the sentence of death passed upon appellant in respect of the offence under s. 302.

anchor.surface_text: and confirming the sentence of death passed upon him in respect of the offence under s. 302 and also affirming the sentences passed in respect of the other two offences.

facts.text: Appellant quarrelled with Mangali, PW 1, as Mangali reprimanded him over the grazing of his cattle in Mangali's field and damaging his crops.

anchor.surface_text: The facts as found by the High Court are these The appellant had quarrelled with Mangali, PW 1, as Mangali reprimanded him over the grazing of his cattle in Mangalis field and damaging his crops.

facts.text: Appellant threatened Mangali that he would exterminate the latter's family.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant threatened Mangali that he would exterminate the latters family.

facts.text: On February 25, 1957 at about 3-00 p.m. children were playing in the village near the hut of Hiralal, P.W. 3.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1957 at about 3-00 p.m. Babu Ram son of Mangali, aged about 7 or 8 years, Ram Ratia, aged about 2 years, daughter of Mangalis brother and Punna, son of Baijnath, brother of Mangali and Dulli, daughter of one Ladda Kewat, aged about 10 or 11 years and some other children were playing in the village near the hut of Hiralal, P.W. 3.

facts.text: Children playing: Babu Ram son of Mangali, aged about 7 or 8 years.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1957 at about 3-00 p.m. Babu Ram son of Mangali, aged about 7 or 8 years, Ram Ratia, aged about 2 years, daughter of Mangalis brother

facts.text: Ram Ratia, aged about 2 years, daughter of Mangali's brother.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Ratia, aged about 2 years, daughter of Mangalis brother and Punna, son of Baijnath, brother of Mangali

facts.text: Punna, son of Baijnath, brother of Mangali.

anchor.surface_text: and Punna, son of Baijnath, brother of Mangali and Dulli, daughter of one Ladda Kewat, aged about 10 or 11 years

facts.text: Dulli, daughter of one Ladda Kewat, aged about 10 or 11 years.

anchor.surface_text: and Dulli, daughter of one Ladda Kewat, aged about 10 or 11 years and some other children were playing in the village near the hut of Hiralal, P.W. 3.

facts.text: Appellant came there armed with a sickle and rushed at the children.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant came there armed with a sickle and rushed at the children.

facts.text: Appellant first struck a blow on Babu Ram, who fled away and started crying.

anchor.surface_text: He first struck a blow on Babu Ram, who fled away and started crying.

facts.text: Mangali's one year old daughter Lachhminia was also there at that time.

anchor.surface_text: Mangalis one year old daughter Lachhminia was also there at that time and the appellant ripped open that childs chest with the sickle

facts.text: Appellant ripped open Lachhminia's chest with the sickle as a result of which she died almost immediately.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant ripped open that childs chest with the sickle as a result of which she died almost immediately.

facts.text: Appellant then struck blows on Ram Ratia and also on Punna.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then struck blows on Ram Ratia and also on Punna.

facts.text: Hiralal, the brother of the appellant who was sleeping in his hut was awakened by the cries of children and rushed out to save them.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal, the brother of the appellant who was sleeping in his hut was awakened by the cries of children and rushed out to save them.

facts.text: Appellant struck a blow on Hiralal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant struck a blow on Hiralal as well.

facts.text: Hearing the cries of children a number of villagers rushed to the spot but the appellant escaped from their clutches by running towards the river Ganges.

anchor.surface_text: Hearing the cries of children a number of villagers rushed to the spot but the appellant escaped from their clutches by running towards the river Ganges which is at a distance of about 75 paces from the place of the incident, jumped into the water and swam to the other shore and absconded.

facts.text: River Ganges is at a distance of about 75 paces from the place of the incident.

anchor.surface_text: which is at a distance of about 75 paces from the place of the incident, jumped into the water and swam to the other shore and absconded.

facts.text: Appellant jumped into the water of Ganges and swam to the other shore and absconded.

anchor.surface_text: jumped into the water and swam to the other shore and absconded.

facts.text: On October 11, 1957 proceedings under ss. 87 and 88 of the Code of Criminal Procedure were started against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On October 11, 1957 proceedings under ss. 87 and 88 of the Code of Criminal Procedure were started against him and he was eventually proceeded against as an absconder.

facts.text: Appellant was proceeded against as an absconder.

anchor.surface_text: and he was eventually proceeded against as an absconder.

facts.text: Appellant was arrested on February 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It was only on February 1, 1963 that he was arrested and thereafter sent up for trial.

facts.text: At the trial appellant was convicted and sentenced.

anchor.surface_text: At that trial he was convicted and sentenced, as already stated.

facts.text: Appellant did not plead the defence of insanity in his examination under s. 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: even though in his examination under s. 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the appellant did not plead the defence of insanity.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant urged that appellant was a person of unsound mind.

anchor.surface_text: The only point urged by Mr. Varma who appears for the appellant is that the appellant was a person of unsound mind

facts.text: Hiralal is the brother of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal, the brother of the appellant who was sleeping in his hut

facts.text: Dulli belongs to the family of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: while Dulli, as she herself admits, belongs to the family of the appellant.

facts.text: Court found appellant was sane and case does not fall under s. 84 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: We entirely agree with these observations of the learned Sessions Judge and also with the conclusion arrived at by him that the case of the appellant does not fall under the exception created by s. 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge disbelieved evidence suggesting appellant was of unsound mind.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the learned Sessions Judge disbelieved that part of the evidence of these two witnesses which tended to suggest that the appellant was a person of unsound mind

issues.text: Whether the appellant was a person of unsound mind and not in a position to know or realise the nature of the acts which he was committing?

anchor.surface_text: The only point urged by Mr. Varma who appears for the appellant is that the appellant was a person of unsound mind and that he was number in a position to know or realise the nature of the acts D ,2SCI-16

issues.text: Whether the prosecution must establish the sanity of the accused despite s. 105 of the Evidence Act, or is the burden on the accused to prove the exception?

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

issues.text: Whether the case of the appellant falls under the exception created by s. 84 of the Indian Penal Code?

anchor.surface_text: the case of the appellant does not fall under the exception created by s. 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.court_reasoning: case does not fall under exception in s. 84 IPC; accused failed to prove unsoundness of mind; circumstances indicate sanity

arguments.claim: mens rea being an essential ingredient of all the offences with which the appellant was charged his conviction cannot be sustained as no intention could be attributed to an insane person

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel argued that mens rea being an essential ingredient of all the offences with which the appellant was charged his conviction with respect to any of them cannot be sustained for the simple reason that no intention to cause death or to cause any injury whether resulting in death or not could possibly be attributed to a person who, when he committed the acts, was insane.

arguments.court_reasoning: mens rea proved beyond reasonable doubt from circumstances like deliberate use of deadly weapon; presumption of sanity arises

arguments.claim: prosecution must establish mens rea even if accused did not plead insanity or lead evidence per Dahyabhai

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel, however, relies upon a decision of this Court in Dahyabhai Chhaganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat 1 , and contends that it is for the prosecution to establish the necessary mens rea of the accused and that even though the accused may not have taken the plea of insanity or led any evidence to show that he was insane when he committed an offence of which intention is an ingredient the prosecution must satisfy the court that the accused had the requisite intention.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: gs.  3  Even if the accused was number able to establish companyclusively that he was insane at the time he companymitted the offence, the evidence pl

arguments.court_reasoning: agrees prosecution must prove mens rea but once done presumption of sanity arises which accused must rebut; Dahyabhai does not shift burden to prove sanity

arguments.claim: per Dahyabhai propositions prosecution must prove sanity or at least no reasonable doubt on mens rea despite insanity evidence

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Varma, however, relies upon the following passage occurring in the aforementioned judgment of this Court-- The doctrine of burden of proof in the context of the plea of insanity may be stated in the following propositions (1) The prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had committed the offence with the requisite mens rea and the burden of proving that always rests on the prosecution from the beginning to the end of the trial.

arguments.court_reasoning: passage does not alter s.105 Evidence Act; prosecution proves mens rea, sanity presumed and rebuttable by accused on preponderance

arguments.claim: no man in his senses would attack children indiscriminately and rip open chest of one year old child proving unsound mind

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Varma further contends that there is evidence on record from which it can be inferred that the appellant was a person of unsound mind. In the first place, he points out, that no man in his senses will go on attacking children indiscriminately and go to the length of ripping open the chest of one year old child.

arguments.court_reasoning: brutality shows only brutality of assailant, not unsound mind

arguments.court_reasoning: witnesses interested (family); statements first made in cross-examination; prosecution cross-examined as hostile; earlier statements contradict; disbelieved by Sessions Judge

arguments.claim: Sessions Judge observations indicate doubt about appellant's sanity entitling benefit of doubt

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Varma then relies on the following observations made by the learned Sessions Judge and says that in view of these observations it would appear that the learned Sessions Judge entertained a doubt about the sanity of the appellant and that, therefore, the benefit of that doubt must be given to him.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cannot be discharged merely by creating a doubt about his insanity. We find it difficult to companystrue these observations of the learned Sessions J

arguments.court_reasoning: misconstrues Sessions Judge; he meant burden not discharged by mere doubt; must prove insanity; context shows no doubt

arguments.claim: burden on accused under s.105 Evidence Act to prove exception like insanity; court presumes absence

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

arguments.claim: mens rea inferred from circumstances like deliberately striking with deadly weapon likely to cause death

anchor.surface_text: Thus if a person deliberately strikes another with a deadly weapon, which according to the common experience of mankind is likely to cause an injury and sometimes even a fatal injury depending upon the quality of the weapon and the part of the body on which it is struck, it would be reasonable to infer that what the accused did was accompanied by the intention to cause a kind of injury which in fact resulted from the act.

arguments.claim: everyone presumed to know natural consequences of acts and the law

anchor.surface_text: Everyone is presumed to know the natural consequences of his act. Similarly everyone is also presumed to know the law. These are not facts which the prosecution has to establish.

arguments.claim: Dahyabhai does not require prosecution to prove sanity; only mens rea, then rebuttable presumption of sanity

anchor.surface_text: This passage does not say anything different from what we have said earlier. Undoubtedly it is for the prosecution to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had committed the offence with the requisite mens rea. Once that is done a presumption that the accused was sane when he committed the offence would arise.

arguments.claim: Sessions Judge disbelieved evidence of unsound mind from witnesses

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the learned Sessions Judge disbelieved that part of the evidence of these two witnesses which tended to suggest that the appellant was a person of unsound mind

arguments.claim: appellant conducted normally before incident, had motive from prior quarrel, selectively attacked Mangali family children despite others present, beat intervener only, fled fearing capture showing sanity

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is evidence that up to the time of occurrence he has been doing his cultivation... Lastly, a sense of fear prevailed in him and that is why he acted like a sane man by running and then escaping by jumping into the Ganges river. So, in my view all these circumstances lead to one conclusion that he was not insane and had acted like a sane man and with some motive.

arguments.court_reasoning: entirely agree with these observations of the learned Sessions Judge and also with the conclusion arrived at by him

holdings.text: The prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused committed the offence with the requisite mens rea, as the burden of proving the offence never shifts.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had committed the offence with the requisite mens rea and the burden of proving that always rests on the prosecution from the beginning to the end of the trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mens rea is essential ingredient; inferred from circumstances like deliberate use of deadly weapon; confirmed via precedent in Dahyabhai.

holdings.text: Under s.105 Evidence Act, burden of proving exception like s.84 IPC lies on accused; court presumes absence of such circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision directly applies; prosecution proves offence, accused rebuts presumption of sanity.

holdings.text: Once prosecution proves mens rea, rebuttable presumption arises that accused was sane; accused bears burden to rebut on preponderance of probabilities.

anchor.surface_text: Once that is done a presumption that the accused was sane when he committed the offence would arise. This presumption is rebuttable and he can rebut it either by leading evidence or by relying upon the prosecution evidence itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows s.105 Evidence Act; Dahyabhai propositions (1) and (2) interpreted consistently; burden not on prosecution to prove sanity.

holdings.text: Dahyabhai does not require prosecution to prove sanity of accused; only mens rea, after which sanity presumed unless rebutted.

anchor.surface_text: This passage does not say anything different from what we have said earlier. Undoubtedly it is for the prosecution to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had committed the offence with the requisite mens rea.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Dahyabhai passage; aligns with s.105; prosecution not to disprove insanity ab initio.

holdings.text: Mens rea can be inferred from circumstances, e.g., deliberately striking with deadly weapon likely to cause death or injury.

anchor.surface_text: Thus if a person deliberately strikes another with a deadly weapon, which according to the common experience of mankind is likely to cause an injury and sometimes even a fatal injury depending upon the quality of the weapon and the part of the body on which it is struck, it would be reasonable to infer

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances of deliberate acts with sickle on vital parts prove intention; common knowledge of consequences.

holdings.text: Brutality or indiscriminate attack on children does not prove unsound mind; shows only brutality of assailant.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the indiscriminate manner in which the appellant attacked three innocent children and particularly his act of ripping open the chest of Lachhminia only shows the brutality of the assailant and cannot reasonably be regarded as a circumstance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical inference from facts; such acts consistent with sane revenge motive, not necessarily insanity.

holdings.text: Evidence of interested witnesses (family) on insanity disbelieved; first raised in cross-examination, contradicted earlier statements.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances the learned Sessions Judge disbelieved that part of the evidence of these two witnesses which tended to suggest that the appellant was a person of unsound mind and was known as such the village.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sessions Judge correctly assessed credibility; prosecution cross-examined as hostile; agrees with lower court.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge's observations on burden not indicating doubt on sanity but requiring proof beyond mere doubt.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to construe these observations of the learned Sessions Judge to mean what learned Counsel says they mean... all that the learned Sessions Judge meant by saying by creating a doubt evidently was that by merely trying to throw doubt about his sanity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual reading of lower court judgment; burden requires affirmative proof of insanity.

holdings.text: Circumstances prove appellant sane: prior normal conduct, motive from quarrel, selective attacks on victim's family children, flight fearing capture.

anchor.surface_text: We entirely agree with these observations of the learned Sessions Judge and also with the conclusion arrived at by him that the case of the appellant does not fall under the exception created by s. 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with Sessions Judge: cultivation, threats, deliberation, fear shown by escape; rebuts insanity.

holdings.text: Appellant's case does not fall under exception in s.84 IPC; conviction and death sentence affirmed.

anchor.surface_text: We entirely agree with these observations of the learned Sessions Judge and also with the conclusion arrived at by him that the case of the appellant does not fall under the exception created by s. 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fails burden; circumstances establish knowledge of act's nature/wrongfulness; mens rea proved.

precedents.citation: Dahyabhai Chhaganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat 1

anchor.surface_text: Dahyabhai Chhaganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat 1 , and companytends that it is for the prosecution to establish the necessary mens rea of the accused and that even though the accused may number have taken the plea of insanity or led any evidence to show that he was insane when he companymitted an offence of which intention is an ingredient the prosecution must satisfy the companyrt that the accused had the requisite intention. There is numberdoubt that the burden of proving an offence is always on the prosecution and that it never shifts.

precedents.case_name: Dahyabhai Chhaganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat
precedents.cited_proposition: Prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused committed the offence with requisite mens rea; rebuttable presumption of sanity; accused can raise reasonable doubt via evidence to discharge prosecution burden
precedents.cited_holding: The doctrine of burden of proof in the context of the plea of insanity may be stated in the following propositions: 1. The prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had committed the offence with the requisite mens rea... 3. Even if the accused was not able to establish conclusively that he was insane...

anchor.surface_text: 1964 7 S.C.R. 361. by the intention to cause a kind of injury which in fact resulted from the act. In such a case the prosecution must be deemed to have discharged the burden which rested upon it to establish an essential ingredient of the offence, namely the intention of the accused in inflicting a blow with a deadly weapon. Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code can numberdoubt be invoked by a person for nullifying the evidence adduced by the prosecution by establishing that he was at the relevant time incapable of knowing the-nature of the act or that what he was doing was either wrong or companytrary to law.

anchor.surface_text: We entirely agree with these observations of the learned Sessions Judge and also with the conclusion arrived at by him that the case of the appellant does number fall under the exception created by s. 84

outcome.relief_summary: Insanity defence under Section 84 IPC rejected; conviction under Sections 302, 307 and 324 IPC and death sentence upheld
